cards.title: Drag race / Runners in high heels celebrate pride in Madrid
cards.rawTitle: Runners in high heels celebrate pride in Madrid

item.title: Drag race: runners in high heels celebrate pride in Madrid
item.trailText: Drag queens and runners in sports kit donned heels on Thursday to run in Madrid's annual LGBT pride high-heels race
item.standFirst: Drag queens and runners in sports kit donned heels on Thursday to run in Madrid's annual LGBT pride high-heels race, down a packed street in the gay neighbourhood of Chueca. Heels must be 10cm or higher to qualify and runners must be male. The 2015 winner was Jason from Peru, who received €250, dinner for two and vouchers for local businesses

stillImage.caption: Drag queens and runners in sports kit don heels on Thursday to run in Madrid's traditional LGBT pride high-heels race, down a packed street in the gay neighbourhood of Chueca. 03 July 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters
stillImage.cleanCaption: Drag queens and runners in sports kit don heels on Thursday to run in Madrid's traditional LGBT pride high-heels race, down a packed street in the gay neighbourhood of Chueca. 03 July 2015 Photograph: Reuters

item.title: Curiouser and curiouser: Damon Albarn's wonder.land
item.trailText: Manchester international festival kicks off with the first performance of wonder.land, with music by Damon Albarn and book and lyrics by Moira Buffini, directed by Rufus Norris
item.standFirst: Manchester international festival opens today with the first performance of wonder.land, with music by Damon Albarn and book and lyrics by Moira Buffini, directed by Rufus Norris. Take a closer look at the show

displayImages.caption:
Alice the adventurer … Rob Compton and Rosalie Craig in wonder.land by Damon Albarn and Moira Buffini at Manchester international festival.
All photographs: Brinkhoff/Moegenburg
displayImages.altText: wonder.land
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Alice the adventurer … Rob Compton and Rosalie Craig in wonder.land by Damon Albarn and Moira Buffini at Manchester international festival.
All photographs: Brinkhoff/Moegenburg

displayImages.caption: The show takes inspiration from Lewis Carroll’s Alice in Wonderland and explores the collision between real life and the virtual world. ‘The book is a big challenge to adapt,’ says Moira Buffini, ‘because it doesn’t follow any of the normal rules of narrative.’
displayImages.altText: wonder.land
displayImages.cleanCaption: The show takes inspiration from Lewis Carroll’s Alice in Wonderland and explores the collision between real life and the virtual world. ‘The book is a big challenge to adapt,’ says Moira Buffini, ‘because it doesn’t follow any of the normal rules of narrative.’

displayImages.caption: Rosalie Craig plays schoolgirl Aly, who is bullied at school and escapes into the fantasy online world of wonder.land, where she becomes Alice.
displayImages.altText: wonder.land
displayImages.cleanCaption: Rosalie Craig plays schoolgirl Aly, who is bullied at school and escapes into the fantasy online world of wonder.land, where she becomes Alice.

displayImages.caption: The show is designed by Rae Smith (whose previous productions include War Horse), with projections by 59 Productions. Lighting is by Paule Constable.
displayImages.altText: wonder.land
displayImages.cleanCaption: The show is designed by Rae Smith (whose previous productions include War Horse), with projections by 59 Productions. Lighting is by Paule Constable.

displayImages.caption: Katrina Lindsay designed the costumes. Lindsay is set to design the outfits for the forthcoming Harry Potter play in the West End.
displayImages.altText: wonder.land
displayImages.cleanCaption: Katrina Lindsay designed the costumes. Lindsay is set to design the outfits for the forthcoming Harry Potter play in the West End.

displayImages.caption: ‘The arena that children get lost in these days is the internet: that is the rabbit hole,’ says Buffini.
displayImages.altText: wonder.land
displayImages.cleanCaption: ‘The arena that children get lost in these days is the internet: that is the rabbit hole,’ says Buffini.

displayImages.caption: Lois Chimimba, Paul Hilton and Enyi Okoronkwo in wonder.land.
displayImages.altText: wonder.land
displayImages.cleanCaption: Lois Chimimba, Paul Hilton and Enyi Okoronkwo in wonder.land.

displayImages.caption: Around the world with Alice … wonder.land premieres at Manchester international festival; it will be staged at London’s National Theatre in November 2015 and the Théâtre du Châtelet in Paris in 2016.
displayImages.altText: wonder.land
displayImages.cleanCaption: Around the world with Alice … wonder.land premieres at Manchester international festival; it will be staged at London’s National Theatre in November 2015 and the Théâtre du Châtelet in Paris in 2016.

Alice the adventurer … Rob Compton and Rosalie Craig in wonder.land by Damon Albarn and Moira Buffini at Manchester international festival.
All photographs: Brinkhoff/Moegenburg

cards.title: Thunder, lightning and hail follow British heatwave
cards.rawTitle: Thunder, lightning and hail follow British heatwave

item.title: Thunder, lightning and hail follow British heatwave
item.trailText: Spectacular lightning sweeps across northern England and Scotland after the hottest July day on record in many places
item.standFirst: Spectacular lightning sweeps across northern England and Scotland after the hottest July day on record in many places. The thunderstorm left 40,000 homes without electricity in parts of North Yorkshire, County Durham, Tyne and Wear and Northumberland. Elsewhere, huge hailstones caused damage to roofs and cars

displayImages.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Weather Photograph: guardian.co.uk

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: days three and four

displayImages.caption: Shout out to Andy Murray who cruised into the third round with a commanding 6-1, 6-1, 6-4 victory over a disappointing Robin Haase. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Shout out to Andy Murray who cruised into the third round with a commanding 6-1, 6-1, 6-4 victory over a disappointing Robin Haase
displayImages.cleanCaption: Shout out to Andy Murray who cruised into the third round with a commanding 6-1, 6-1, 6-4 victory over a disappointing Robin Haase.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: The Duchess of Cornwall claims the sweatband thrown to the crowd by Andy Murray after his victory. “I heard that she was coming today,” Murray said in his press conference. “I saw her briefly after the match. But the wristband actually hit the chairman of Wimbledon. He was there with her. Normally you see who catches it. Then the Duchess opened up her bag and my wristband was in there, so he obviously had given it to her.”  Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, claims the sweatband thrown to the crowd by Andy Murray after his victory. “I heard that she was coming today,” Murray said in his press conference. “I saw her briefly after the match. But the wristband actually hit the chairman of Wimbledon. He was there with her. Normally you see who catches it. Then the Duchess opened up her bag and my wristband was in there, so he obviously had given it to her.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Duchess of Cornwall claims the sweatband thrown to the crowd by Andy Murray after his victory. “I heard that she was coming today,” Murray said in his press conference. “I saw her briefly after the match. But the wristband actually hit the chairman of Wimbledon. He was there with her. Normally you see who catches it. Then the Duchess opened up her bag and my wristband was in there, so he obviously had given it to her.”
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Roger Federer was in impressive form during his victory over Sam Querrey. “I’m very happy with the way I’m playing,” he said. “I’ve been playing well this season, really since here last year. It’s also a bit of a relief to be playing well at Wimbledon.” Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Roger Federer was in impressive form during his victory over Sam Querrey. “I’m very happy with the way I’m playing,” he said. “I’ve been playing well this season, really since here last year. It’s also a bit of a relief to be playing well at Wimbledon.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Roger Federer was in impressive form during his victory over Sam Querrey. “I’m very happy with the way I’m playing,” he said. “I’ve been playing well this season, really since here last year. It’s also a bit of a relief to be playing well at Wimbledon.”
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Rafael Nadal was knocked out of Wimbledon in the first week for the third time in four years after losing to Dustin Brown 7-5, 3-6, 6-4, 6-4. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Finally to the match between Rafael Nadal and Dustin Brown on Centre Court where Rafa was knocked out of Wimbledon in the first week for the third time in four years.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Rafael Nadal was knocked out of Wimbledon in the first week for the third time in four years after losing to Dustin Brown 7-5, 3-6, 6-4, 6-4.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Brown celebrates after his victory. “I’d never been on the Centre Court before and I thought I would freak out,” Brown said. “I don’t know if it was because I had beaten him in Halle [in 2014] but I felt comfortable. I had nothing to lose and that made it a lot easier for me.” Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Dustin Brown celebrates after his victory. “I’d never been on the Centre Court before and I thought I would freak out,” Brown said. “I don’t know if it was because I had beaten him in Halle [in 2014] but I felt comfortable. I had nothing to lose and that made it a lot easier for me.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Brown celebrates after his victory. “I’d never been on the Centre Court before and I thought I would freak out,” Brown said. “I don’t know if it was because I had beaten him in Halle [in 2014] but I felt comfortable. I had nothing to lose and that made it a lot easier for me.”
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: “It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues,” Rafa said after the match. “My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.” Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: “It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues,” Rafa said after the match. “My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: “It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues,” Rafa said after the match. “My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.”
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

image.caption: Brown celebrates after his victory. “I’d never been on the Centre Court before and I thought I would freak out,” Brown said. “I don’t know if it was because I had beaten him in Halle [in 2014] but I felt comfortable. I had nothing to lose and that made it a lot easier for me.” Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
image.altText: Dustin Brown celebrates after his victory. “I’d never been on the Centre Court before and I thought I would freak out,” Brown said. “I don’t know if it was because I had beaten him in Halle [in 2014] but I felt comfortable. I had nothing to lose and that made it a lot easier for me.”
image.cleanCaption: Brown celebrates after his victory. “I’d never been on the Centre Court before and I thought I would freak out,” Brown said. “I don’t know if it was because I had beaten him in Halle [in 2014] but I felt comfortable. I had nothing to lose and that made it a lot easier for me.”
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

image.caption: “It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues,” Rafa said after the match. “My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.” Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
image.altText: “It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues,” Rafa said after the match. “My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.”
image.cleanCaption: “It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues,” Rafa said after the match. “My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.”
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

cards.title: Why La Grande Bouffe is the film you should watch this week
cards.rawTitle: Why La Grande Bouffe is the film you should watch this week

item.title: Why La Grande Bouffe is the film you should watch this week – video review
item.trailText: Marco Ferreri's 1973 jaded, perverted satire of decadence and conceit is still jawdropping, says Peter Bradshaw
item.standFirst: Marco Ferreri's 1973 film is something else: jaded, perverted, and drenched in ennui, says Peter Bradshaw. Starring Marcello Mastroianni, Ugo Tognazzi, Michel Piccoli and Philippe Noiret, it is ostensibly about four men who get together to eat themselves to death. La Grande Bouffe – aka Blow Out – is a still-jawdropping satire of decadence and conceit. It is re-released in cinemas today

cards.title: Photo highlights of the day / Lake Balaton, Hungary

item.title: Photo highlights of the day: own goals and thunderstorms
item.trailText: The Greek crisis, thunderstorms following the hottest day in the UK, and the largest lake race for yachts in Europe

cards.title: Laura Bassett’s mother / 'It was hard to see her cry'
cards.rawTitle: 'It was hard to see her cry'

item.title: Laura Bassett’s mother: it was hard to see her cry
item.trailText: The mother of Laura Bassett says it was tough to watch her daughter cry after scoring the injury-time own-goal that cost England a place in the World Cup final
item.standFirst: The mother of Laura Bassett says it was tough to watch her daughter cry after scoring the injury-time own-goal that cost England a place in the World Cup final. Speaking to ITV News Central, Marie Bassett says it was a 'surreal moment', but she is confident Laura will 'bounce back'. The defender was in tears after slicing an intended clearance into her own net in the 2-1 defeat to Japan
